data.meta_description:

i feel like it just sounds better but its clearly a rim shot.
data.text:
Only if I want that sort of sound?

I don't know what you're asking. I'll use it during fills and stuff like that, but NEVER as my go-to snare hit. It lacks any kid of body and snap that you would want.

If you're enjoying that more than a regular snare I would go back and look at how you processed your snare bus, cause you should be able to get a pretty good snare with a small handful of tweaking.

I'll politely disagree here.

If you want to write drums like a drummer, you have to think like a drummer.

Rim shots are - like palm mutes - a technique that gives a certain sound and feel to things. It's very often used in actual drumming.

I use both. Always.

i agree with this but i do also feel what hes saying in that if im using the rim shot sound as the main snare its probably because i dont like the snare sample or am not giving it a chance with processing. i may try to combine both! i just felt that the rim shot kind of had that metal "pop" so to speak.

Try increasing the attack on the compressor. I go as high as 100ms on very 'natural' sounding snares and it tends to slightly even-out rim-shots with open hits.

Give it a go, see if you like it. Ratio has to be 3:0 or more and threshold low enough to cause a 4-6db reduction.

Rimshots are very important in general to get a good smack out of the snare but for some reason I never found superior drummer rimshots usable for anything. If you are using superior drummer chances are you are also using a compressor, so it's not very hard to get good cracking snares with the regular hits, which will have a lot more low end and body to them.

But still this only applies to this particular program, rimshots are absolutely essential in "heavy" drumming in general.

Glenn Fricker said in one of his YouTube videos that he'll often ask drummers to use rimshots as their main snare hit. Something about better attack, I think?

You could always program your drums with normal hits and then blend in rimshots with a lower velocity to fill out the sound.
